Randall signature.tif | footnotes = }} '''Samuel Jackson Randall''' (October 10, 1828 – April 13, 1890) was a [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic]] member of the [[United States House of Representatives]] from [[Pennsylvania]] in the late 19th century. He served as the 29th [[Speaker of the United States House of Representatives|Speaker of the House]] and was twice a contender for his party's nomination for [[President of the United States]]. Born in [[Philadelphia]] to a family active in [[Whig Party (United States)|Whig]] politics, Randall shifted to the Democratic Party after the Whigs' demise. His rise in politics began in the 1850s with election to the Philadelphia Common Council and then to the [[Pennsylvania State Senate]]. Randall served in a Union cavalry unit in the [[American Civil War]] before winning a seat in the federal House of Representatives in 1862. He was reelected every two years thereafter until his death. The representative of an industrial region, Randall became known as a staunch defender of [[protectionism|protective tariffs]] designed to assist domestic producers of manufactured goods. While often siding with [[Republican Party (United States)|Republicans]] on tariff issues, he differed with them in his resistance to [[Reconstruction Era|Reconstruction]] and the growth of federal power. Randall's defense of smaller, less centralized government raised his profile among House Democrats, and they elevated him to Speaker in 1876. He held that post until the Democrats lost control of the House in 1881, and was considered a possible nominee for President in 1880 and 1884. Randall's support for high tariffs began to alienate him from most Democrats, and when that party regained control of the House in 1883, he was denied another term as Speaker. Randall continued to serve in Congress as head of the [[United States House Committee on Appropriations|Appropriations Committee]]. He remained a respected party leader, but gradually lost influence as the Democrats became more firmly wedded to [[free trade]]. Worsening health also curtailed his power until his death in 1890. ==Early life and family== Randall was born on October 10, 1828 in [[Philadelphia, Pennsylvania]], the eldest son of Josiah and Ann Worrell Randall.{{sfn|Memorial 1891|pp=6–7}} Three younger brothers soon followed: William, Robert, and Henry.{{sfn|House|1934|p=2}} Josiah Randall was a leading Philadelphia lawyer who had served in the [[Pennsylvania General Assembly|state legislature]] in the 1820s.{{sfn|Scharf|1884|p=595}} Randall's paternal grandfather, Matthew Randall, was a judge on the [[Pennsylvania Courts of Common Pleas]] and county [[prothonotary]] in that city in the early 19th century.{{sfn|Memorial 1891|pp=6–7, 119}} His maternal grandfather, Joseph Worrell, was also a prominent citizen, active in politics for the [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic Party]] during [[Thomas Jefferson]]'s presidency.{{sfn|House|1934|p=2}} Josiah Randall was a [[Whig Party (United States)|Whig]] in politics, but drifted into the Democratic fold after the Whig Party dissolved in the 1850s.{{sfn|House|1934|pp=4–5}} When Randall was born, the family lived at Seventh and Walnut Streets in what is now [[Center City Philadelphia]].{{sfn|House|1934|p=2}} Randall was educated at the University Academy, a school affiliated with the [[University of Pennsylvania]].{{sfn|Memorial 1891|pp=6–7}} On completing school at age 17, he did not follow his father into the law, but instead took a job as a [[Bookkeeping|bookkeeper]] with a local silk merchant.{{sfn|Memorial 1891|p=120}} Shortly thereafter, he started a coal delivery business and, at age 21, became a partner in a scrap iron business named Earp and Randall.{{sfn|House|1934|p=3}} Two years later, in 1851, Randall married Fannie Agnes Ward, the daughter of [[Aaron Ward (representative)|Aaron]] and Mary Watson Ward of [[Ossining (village), New York|Sing Sing]], New York.{{sfn|Ward|1910|p=348}} Randall's new father-in-law was a major general in the New York militia and had served in Congress as a [[Jacksonian democracy|Jacksonian Democrat]] for several terms between 1825 and 1843.{{sfn|Ward|1910|p=245}} Randall and Fannie went on to have three children: Ann, Susan, and Samuel Josiah.{{sfn|Ward|1910|p=348}} ==Local politics and military service== In 1851, Randall assisted his father in the election campaign for a local judge.{{sfn|House|1934|p=3}} The judge, a Whig, was elected despite considerable opposition from a candidate of the nativist [[Know Nothing|American Party]] (commonly called the "Know-Nothing Party").{{sfn|House|1934|p=3}} The strength of this group, combined with the Whigs' declining fortunes, led Samuel Randall to call himself an "American Whig" when he ran for [[Philadelphia City Council|Philadelphia Common Council]] the following year.{{sfn|House|1934|p=3}} He was elected, holding office for four one-year terms from 1852 to 1856.{{sfn|House|1934|p=3}} The period was one of significant change in Philadelphia's governance, as all of [[Philadelphia County, Pennsylvania|Philadelphia County]]'s townships and boroughs [[Act of Consolidation, 1854|were consolidated]] into one city in 1854.{{sfn|Memorial 1891|p=36}} [[File:First Troop Armory.tif|thumb|left|Randall served in the First City Troop of Philadelphia Cavalry ''(headquarters shown)'' in 1861 and 1863.]] As the Whig Party fell apart, Randall and his family became Democrats.{{sfn|Memorial 1891|p=120}} Josiah Randall was friendly with [[James Buchanan]], a Pennsylvania Democrat then serving as the United States' [[United States Ambassador to the United Kingdom|envoy in Great Britain]].{{sfn|House|1934|p=4}} Both Randall and his father attended the [[1856 Democratic National Convention|Democratic National Convention]] in 1856 to work for Buchanan's nomination for president, which was successful.{{sfn|House|1934|p=5}} When, in 1858, a vacancy occurred in Randall's [[Pennsylvania State Senate|state Senate]] district, he ran for election (as a Democrat) for the remainder of the term, and was elected.{{sfn|House|1934|p=5}} Still only 30 years old, Randall had risen rapidly in politics. Much of his term in the state Senate was spent dealing with the incorporation of [[Horsecar|street railway]] companies, which he believed would benefit his district.{{sfn|House|1934|pp=6–7}} Randall also supported legislation to reduce the power of banks, a policy that he would continue to advocate for his entire political career.{{sfn|House|1934|pp=6–7}} In 1860, he ran for election to a full term in the state Senate while his brother Robert ran for a seat in the [[Pennsylvania House of Representatives|state House of Representatives]].{{sfn|Memorial 1891|p=121}} Ignoring their father's advice that it meant "too much Randall on the ticket," both brothers were unsuccessful.{{sfn|Memorial 1891|p=121}} In 1861, the [[American Civil War|Civil War]] began as eleven Southern states seceded from the Union to form the [[Confederate States of America]]. Randall joined the [[First Troop Philadelphia City Cavalry]] in May of that year as a [[Private (rank)|private]].{{sfn|House|1934|pp=8–9}} The unit was stationed in central Pennsylvania and eastern Virginia during Randall's 90-day enlistment, but saw no action during that time.{{sfn|House|1934|pp=8–9}} In 1863, he re-joined the unit, this time being elected [[captain (United States)|captain]].{{sfn|Memorial 1891|p=121}} The First Troop was sent back to central Pennsylvania during the [[Gettysburg campaign]] that summer, when Confederate forces under [[Robert E. Lee]] invaded Pennsylvania.{{sfn|Memorial 1891|p=121}} He served as [[provost marshal]] at [[Gettysburg, Pennsylvania]] in the days before [[battle of Gettysburg|the battle there]], and had the same role at [[Columbia, Pennsylvania]] during the battle, but did not see combat.{{sfn|House|1934|pp=8–9}} As historian Albert V. House explained, "[h]is military career was respectable, but far from arduous, most of his duties being routine reconnoitering which seldom led him under fire."{{sfn|House|1934|pp=8–9}} {{Clear}} == House of Representatives == ===Election to the House=== [[File:1st Cong Dist PA 1860.png|thumb|Pennsylvania's first congressional district in 1862 (outlined in red)]] In 1862, before rejoining his cavalry unit, Randall was elected to the [[United States House of Representatives]] from [[Pennsylvania's 1st congressional district]].{{sfn|Memorial 1891|p=122}} The city had been [[gerrymandering|gerrymandered]] by a [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] legislature to create four solidly Republican districts, with the result that as many Democrats as possible were lumped into the 1st district.{{sfn|House|1934|pp=8–9}} Gaining the Democratic nomination was, thus, tantamount to election; Randall defeated former mayor [[Richard Vaux]] for their party's endorsement and won easily over his Republican opponent, Edward G. Webb.{{sfnm|Memorial 1891||1p=122|Dubin|1998|2p=195}} He won with the help of William "Squire" McMullen, the Democratic [[Political boss|boss]] of the fourth ward, who would remain a lifelong Randall ally.{{sfn|House|1934|p=10}} Under the congressional calendar of the 1860s, members of the [[38th United States Congress]], elected in November 1862, did not begin their work until December 1863. Randall arrived that month, after being discharged from his cavalry unit, to join a Congress dominated by Republicans.{{sfn|House|1934|p=12}} As a member of the minority, Randall had little opportunity to author legislation, but quickly became known as a hard-working and conscientious member.{{sfn|Memorial 1891|p=122}} [[James G. Blaine]], a Republican also first elected in 1862, later characterized Randall as "a strong partisan, with many elements of leadership. He ... never neglects his public duties, and never forgets the interests of the Democratic Party."{{sfn|Blaine|1886|p=566}} Randall was known as a friend to the manufacturers in his district, especially as it concerned [[Protectionism|protective tariffs]].{{sfn|House|1935|p=350}} Despite being in the minority, Randall spoke often in defense of his constituents' interests.{{sfn|House|1934|pp=13–14}} As House described him, {{blockquote|He had a tongue that could snap out sarcastic quips with lightning speed. His voice was pitched rather high, and in moments of excitement, its metallic ring approached a shrill screech. His countenance was usually very attractive ... but this face became a thundercloud when he was in a defiant mood.{{sfn|House|1934|pp=13–14}}}} With his party continually in the minority, Randall gained experience in the functioning of the House, but his tenure left little evidence in the statute book.{{sfn|House|1934|pp=13–14}} He attracted little attention, but kept his constituents happy and was repeatedly reelected.{{sfn|Memorial 1891|p=123}} ===War and Reconstruction=== [[File:Samuel J. Randall c.1865.tif|thumb|Randall shortly after his election to Congress]] When the 38th Congress convened in December 1863, the Civil War was approaching its end. Randall was a [[War Democrats|War Democrat]], sometimes siding with his Republican colleagues to support measures in pursuit of victory over the Confederates.{{sfn|Memorial 1891|p=123}} When a bill was proposed to allow President [[Abraham Lincoln]] to promote [[Ulysses S. Grant]] to [[Lieutenant general (United States)|lieutenant general]], Randall voted in favor, unlike most in his party.{{sfn|Memorial 1891|p=123}} He voted with the majority of Democrats, however, to oppose allowing [[United States Colored Troops|black men to serve]] in the [[Union Army]].{{sfn|Foley|2013|p=484}} When it came to political plans for the post-war nation, he was strictly opposed to most Republican-proposed measures.{{sfn|House|1934|p=16}} Republicans proposed the [[Thirteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution|Thirteenth Amendment]] to the Constitution in 1865, which would abolish [[Slavery in the United States|slavery]], and Randall spoke against it.{{sfn|House|1934|p=16}} Claiming opposition to slavery, Randall said his objections stemmed instead from a belief that the amendment was "a beginning of changes in the Constitution and the forerunner of usurpation."{{sfn|Memorial 1891|p=123}} After [[Andrew Johnson]] became president following [[Assassination of Abraham Lincoln|Lincoln's assassination]], Randall came to support Johnson's policies for [[Reconstruction Era|Reconstruction]] of the defeated South, which were more lenient than those of the Republican majority in Congress.{{sfn|House|1940|pp=51–52}} In 1867, the Republicans proposed requiring an [[ironclad oath]] from all Southerners wishing to vote, hold office, or practice law in federal courts, making them swear they had never borne arms against the United States.{{sfn|House|1940|p=54}} Randall led a 16-hour [[filibuster]] against the measure; in spite of his efforts, it passed.{{sfn|House|1940|p=54}} Randall began to gain prominence in the small Democratic caucus by opposing Reconstruction measures. His delaying tactics against fellow Pennsylvanian [[Thaddeus Stevens]]'s military Reconstruction bill in February 1867 kept the bill from being considered for two weeks—long enough to prevent it from being voted on until the next session.{{sfn|House|1940|p=55}} He likewise spoke against what would become the [[Fourteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution|Fourteenth Amendment]] to the Constitution.{{sfn|House|1934|p=19}} Although he opposed the amendment, Randall did favor the idea behind part of it: [[Fourteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution#Validity of public debt|section 4]], which guarantees that Congress may not repudiate the federal debt, nor may it assume debts of the Confederacy, nor debt that the individual Confederate states incurred during the rebellion.{{sfn|House|1934|p=23}} Many Republicans claimed that if the Democrats were to regain power, they would do exactly that, repudiating federal debt and assuming that of the rebels.{{sfn|House|1934|p=24}} Despite disagreement on other facets of Reconstruction, Randall stood firmly with the Republicans (and most Northern Democrats) on the debt.{{sfn|House|1934|p=24}} As [[Impeachment in the United States|impeachment]] proceedings began [[Impeachment of Andrew Johnson|against President Johnson]], Randall became one of his leading defenders in the House.{{sfn|House|1934|p=22}} Once the House determined to impeach Johnson, Randall worked to direct the investigation to the [[United States House Committee on the Judiciary|Judiciary Committee]], rather than a special committee convened for the purpose, which he believed would be stacked with pro-impeachment members.{{sfn|House|1934|p=22}} His efforts were unsuccessful, as were his speeches in favor of the president: Johnson was impeached by a vote of 128 to 47.{{sfn|Trefousse|1989|p=315}} Johnson was not convicted after his Senate trial, and Randall remained on good terms with him after the president left office.{{sfn|House|1934|p=23}} ===Financial legislation=== [[File:Southwark Foundry and Machine.png|thumb|left|Philadelphia industrial workers benefited from Randall's support for high tariffs.]] With Grant, a Republican, [[United States presidential election, 1868|elected president]] in 1868, and the [[41st United States Congress|41st Congress]] as Republican-dominated as its immediate predecessors, Randall faced several more years in the minority. He served on the [[United States House Committee on Financial Services|Banking and Currency Committee]] and began to focus on financial matters, resuming his long-standing policy against the power of banks.{{sfn|House|1934|p=24}} This placed Randall in the growing fight over the nature of the nation's currency—those who favored the gold-backed currency were called "hard money" supporters, while the policy of encouraging inflation through coining silver or issuing dollars backed by government bonds ("[[United States Note|greenbacks]]") was known as "soft money".{{sfn|House|1934|pp=47–49}} Although he believed in a gold-backed dollar, Randall was friendly to greenbacks; in general, he favored allowing the amount of currency to remain constant, while replacing bank-issued dollar bills with greenbacks.{{sfn|House|1934|pp=47–49}} He also believed the federal government should sell its bonds directly to the public, rather than selling them only to large banks, which then re-sold them at a profit.{{sfn|House|1934|p=25}} He was unsuccessful in convincing the Republican majority to adopt any of these measures.{{sfn|House|1934|p=24}} Randall worked with Republicans to shift the source of federal funds from taxes to tariffs.{{sfn|House|1934|p=29}} He believed the [[Excise tax in the United States|taxation of alcohol]] spread the burdens of taxation unfairly, especially as concerned his constituents, who included several distillers.{{sfn|House|1934|p=29}} He also believed the [[income tax]], first enacted during the Civil War, was being administered unfairly, with large refunds often accruing to powerful business interests.{{sfn|House|1934|p=29}} On this point, Randall was successful, and the House accepted an amendment that required all cases for refunds over $500 to be tried before a [[United States district court|federal district court]].{{sfn|House|1934|p=29}} He also worked toward the elimination of taxation on tea, coffee, cigars, and matches, all of which Randall believed fell disproportionately on the poor.{{sfn|House|1934|p=30}} Relief from taxation made these items cheaper for the average American, while increasing reliance on tariffs helped the industrial owners and workers in Randall's district, as it made foreign products more expensive.{{sfn|House|1934|p=31}} Tariff legislation generally found favor with Randall, which put him more often in alliance with Republicans than Democrats.{{sfn|Memorial 1891|pp=30, 69}} In the late 1860s and early 1870s, Randall worked to raise tariffs on a wide variety of imported goods.{{sfn|House|1934|p=31}} Even so, he sometimes differed with the Republicans when he believed the tariff proposed was too high; biographer Alfred V. House describes Randall's attitude as supporting "higher tariff rates ... largely because he believed that the benefits of such high rates were passed on to the labor population."{{sfn|House|1934|p=32}} In 1870, he opposed the [[pig iron]] tariff as too high, against the wishes of fellow Pennsylvanian [[William D. Kelley|William "Pig Iron" Kelley]].{{sfn|House|1934|p=33}} Randall called his version of protectionism "incidental protection": he believed that tariffs should be high enough to support the cost of running the government, but only applied to those industries that needed tariff protection to survive foreign competition.{{sfn|House|1934|p=222}} ===Appropriations and investigations=== While the Democrats were in the minority, Randall spent much of his time scrutinizing the Republicans' appropriations bills.{{sfn|House|1934|p=35}} During the [[Ulysses S. Grant presidential administration|Grant administration]], he questioned thousands of items in the appropriation bills, often gaining the support of Republicans in excising expenditures that were in excess of the departments' needs.{{sfn|House|1934|p=36}}{{sfn|House|1935|p=350}} He proposed a bill that would end the practice, common at the time, of executive departments spending beyond what they had been appropriated, then petitioning Congress to retroactively approve the spending with a supplemental appropriation; the legislation passed and became law.{{sfn|House|1934|p=36}} The supplemental appropriations were typically rushed through at the end of a session with little debate.{{sfn|House|1934|p=36}} Reacting to the large grants of land given to railroads, he also sought unsuccessfully to ban all land grants to private corporations.{{sfn|House|1934|pp=38–39}} Investigating appropriations led Randall to focus on financial impropriety in Congress and [[Ulysses S. Grant presidential administration scandals|the Grant administration]].{{sfn|House|1935|p=350}} The most famous of these was the [[Crédit Mobilier of America scandal|Crédit Mobilier scandal]].{{sfn|House|1935|p=350}} In this scheme, the [[Union Pacific Railroad]] bankrupted itself by overpaying its construction company, the Crédit Mobilier of America.{{sfn|House|1934|pp=40–42}} Crédit Mobilier was owned by the railroad's principal shareholders and, as the investigation discovered, several congressmen also owned shares that they had been allowed to purchase at discounted prices.{{sfn|House|1934|pp=40–42}} Randall's role in the investigation was limited, but he proposed bills to ban such frauds and sought to impeach Vice President [[Schuyler Colfax]], who had been implicated in the scandal.{{sfn|House|1934|pp=40–42}} Randall was involved with the investigation of several other scandals, as well, including tax fraud by private tax collection contractors (known as the [[Sanborn incident]]){{sfn|House|1934|pp=42–43}} and fraud in the awarding of postal contracts (the [[star route scandal]]).{{sfn|House|1935|p=350}} Randall was caught on the wrong side of one scandal in 1873 when Congress passed a retroactive pay increase.{{sfn|House|1935|p=350}} On the last day of the term, the [[42nd United States Congress|42nd Congress]] voted to raise its members' pay by 50%, including a raise made retroactive to the beginning of the term.{{sfn|Alston et al. 2006|p=674}} Randall voted for the pay raise, and against the amendment that would have removed the retroactive provision.{{sfn|House|1934|p=45}} The law, later known as the [[Salary Grab Act]], provoked outrage across the country.{{sfn|Alston et al. 2006|p=674}} Randall defended the Act, saying that an increased salary would "put members of Congress beyond temptation" and reduce fraud.{{sfn|Alston et al. 2006|p=689}} Seeing the unpopularity of the Salary Grab, the incoming [[43rd United States Congress|43rd Congress]] repealed it almost immediately, with Randall voting for repeal.{{sfnm|Alston et al. 2006||1p=674|McPherson|1874|2p=27}} ===Rise to prominence=== [[File:Michael C. Kerr - Brady-Handy.jpg|thumb|left|[[Michael C. Kerr]] defeated Randall in the election for Speaker in 1875, but died in 1876.]] Democrats remained in the minority when the 43rd Congress convened in 1873. Randall continued his opposition to measures proposed by Republicans, especially those intended to increase the power of the federal government.{{sfn|Memorial 1891|p=125}} That term saw the introduction of [[Civil Rights Act of 1875|a new civil rights bill]] with farther-reaching ambitions than any before it. [[Enforcement Act of 1871 (third act)|Previous acts]] had seen the use of federal courts and troops to guarantee that black men and women could not be deprived of their civil rights by any state.{{sfn|Wyatt-Brown|1965|p=763}} Now Senator [[Charles Sumner]] of Massachusetts proposed a new bill, aimed at requiring equal rights in all [[public accommodations]].{{sfn|Wyatt-Brown|1965|p=763}} When Sumner died in 1874, his bill had not passed, but others from the [[Radical Republican|radical wing]] of the Republican Party, including Representative [[Benjamin Butler (politician)|Benjamin Butler]] of Massachusetts, continued to work for its enactment.{{sfn|Wyatt-Brown|1965|p=769}} Randall stood against this measure, as he had against nearly all Reconstruction laws.{{sfn|House|1935|p=350}} A lack of consensus delayed the bill from coming to a vote until the [[lame-duck session]] beginning in December 1874.{{sfn|Wyatt-Brown|1965|p=771}} By that time, disillusionment with the Grant administration and worsening economic conditions had translated into a Democratic victory in [[United States House of Representatives elections, 1874|the mid-term elections]].{{sfn|Wyatt-Brown|1965|p=771}} When the [[44th United States Congress|44th Congress]] gathered in March 1875, the House would have a Democratic majority for the first time since the Civil War.{{sfn|Wyatt-Brown|1965|p=771}} In the meantime, the outgoing Republicans made one last effort to pass Sumner's civil rights bill; Randall and other Democrats immediately used parliamentary maneuvers to bring action to a stand-still, hoping to delay passage until the Congress ended.{{sfn|Wyatt-Brown|1965|p=771}} Randall led his caucus in filibustering the bill, at one point remaining on the floor for 72 hours.{{sfn|Memorial 1891|p=125}} In the end, the Democrats peeled away some Republican votes, but not enough to defeat the bill, which passed by a vote of 162 to 100.{{sfn|Wyatt-Brown|1965|p=774}} Despite the defeat, Randall's filibuster increased his prominence in the eyes of his Democratic colleagues.{{sfn|House|1934|p=58}} As Democrats took control of the House in 1875, Randall was considered among the candidates for [[Speaker of the United States House of Representatives|Speaker of the House]].{{sfn|House|1965|pp=255–256}} Many in the caucus hesitated, however, believing Randall to be too close to railroad interests and uncertain on the money question.{{sfn|House|1965|pp=262–268}} His leadership in the Salary Grab may have harmed him, as well.{{sfn|House|1934|pp=62–63}} Randall was also occupied by an intra-party battle with [[William A. Wallace]] for control of the Pennsylvania Democratic Party.{{sfn|House|1934|pp=68–70}} Wallace, who had been elected to the United States Senate in 1874, was weakened by rumors that he had taken bribes from the railroads while a member of the State Senate.{{sfn|House|1956|p=251}} Randall wanted control of the Democratic machine statewide, and the Wallace faction's vulnerability on the bribery rumors provided the opportunity.{{sfn|House|1956|p=252}} In January 1875, he had friends in the state legislature begin an investigation into Wallace's clique, which ultimately turned state Democratic leaders against the senator.{{sfn|House|1956|pp=256–260}} At the state Democratic convention in September 1875, Randall (with the help of his old ally, Squire McMullen) triumphed, putting his men in control of the state party.{{sfn|House|1956|pp=260–265}} In the meantime, the divisions in the state party proved ruinous for Randall's chances at the Speaker's chair.{{sfn|House|1965|pp=269–270}} Instead, the Democrats decided on [[Michael C. Kerr]] of Indiana, who was elected.{{sfn|House|1965|pp=269–270}} Randall was instead named chairman of the [[United States House Committee on Appropriations|Appropriations Committee]].{{sfn|Memorial 1891|p=125}} In that post, he focused on reducing the government's spending, and cut the budget by $30,000,000, despite opposition from the Republican Senate.{{sfn|House|1935|p=350}} Kerr's health was fragile, and he was often absent from sessions, but Randall refused to take his place as speaker on a temporary basis, preferring to concentrate on his appropriations work.{{sfn|House|1934|pp=84–89}} Kerr and Randall began to work more closely together through 1876, but Kerr died in August of that year, leaving the Speakership vacant once again.{{sfn|House|1934|pp=84–89}} ==Speaker of the House== ===Hayes and Tilden=== [[File:Electoral Commission (United States).jpg|thumb|The [[Electoral Commission (United States)|Electoral Commission]] decided the disputed 1876 presidential election.]] After Kerr's death, Randall was the consensus choice of the Democratic caucus, and was elected to the Speakership when Congress returned to Washington on December 2, 1876.{{sfn|House|1934|p=92}} He assumed the chair at a tumultuous time, as [[United States presidential election, 1876|the presidential election]] had just concluded the previous month with no clear winner.{{sfn|House|1934|pp=90–91}} The Democratic candidate, [[Samuel J. Tilden]] of New York, had 184 [[Electoral College (United States)|electoral votes]], just shy of the 185 needed for victory.{{sfn|Robinson|2001|pp=126–127, 141}} [[Rutherford B. Hayes]], the Republican, had 163; the remaining 22 votes were in doubt.{{sfn|Robinson|2001|pp=126–127, 141}} Randall spent early December in conference with Tilden while committees examined the votes from the disputed states.{{sfn|House|1934|p=93}} The counts of the disputed ballots were inconclusive, with each of the states in question producing two sets of returns: one signed by Democratic officials, the other by Republicans, each claiming victory for their man.{{sfn|Robinson|2001|pp=145–154}} By January 1877, with the question still unresolved, Congress and President Grant agreed to submit the matter to a bipartisan [[Electoral Commission (United States)|Electoral Commission]], which would be authorized to determine the fate of the disputed electoral votes.{{sfn|Robinson|2001|pp=145–154}} Randall supported the idea, believing it the best solution to an intractable problem.{{sfn|House|1934|p=95}} The bill passed, providing for a commission of five representatives, five senators, and five Supreme Court justices.{{sfn|Robinson|2001|p=158}} To ensure partisan balance, there would be seven Democrats and seven Republicans; the fifteenth member was to be a Supreme Court justice chosen by the other four on the commission (themselves two Republicans and two Democrats). Justice [[David Davis (Supreme Court justice)|David Davis]], an independent respected by both parties, was expected to be their choice, but he upset the careful planning by accepting election to the Senate by the state of Illinois and refusing to serve on the commission.{{sfn|House|1934|p=96}} The remaining Supreme Court justices were all Republicans and, with the addition of Justice [[Joseph P. Bradley]] to the place intended for Davis, the commission had an 8–7 Republican majority.{{sfn|Robinson|2001|pp=159–161}} Randall nevertheless favored the compromise, even voting in favor of it in the roll call vote (the Speaker usually does not vote).{{sfn|House|1934|p=97}} The commission met and awarded all of the disputed ballots to Hayes by an 8–7 party-line vote.{{sfn|Robinson|2001|pp=166–171}} Democrats were outraged, and many demanded that they filibuster the final count in the House.{{sfn|Foley|2013|p=491}} Randall did not commit, but permitted the House to take recesses several times, delaying the decision.{{sfn|House|1934|p=103}} As the March 4 inauguration day approached, leaders of both parties met at [[Wormley's Hotel]] in Washington to negotiate [[Compromise of 1877|a compromise]]. Republicans promised that, in exchange for Democratic acquiescence in the Commission's decision, Hayes would order federal troops to withdraw from the South and accept the election of Democratic governments in the remaining "[[Redeemers|unredeemed]]" states there.{{sfn|Robinson|2001|pp=182–184}} The Democratic leadership, including Randall, agreed and the filibuster ended.{{sfn|Robinson|2001|pp=185–189}} ===Monetary disputes=== [[File:1879S Morgan Dollar NGC MS67plus Obverse.png|thumb|Randall sided with the majority of Democrats in authorizing [[Dollar coin (United States)|silver dollar]]s, such as this one, in 1878.]] Randall returned to Washington in March 1877 at the start of the [[45th United States Congress|45th Congress]] and was reelected Speaker.{{sfn|House|1934|p=109}} As the session began, many in the Democratic caucus were determined to repeal the [[Specie Payment Resumption Act]] of 1875.{{sfn|House|1934|p=124}} That Act, passed when Republicans last controlled the House, was intended to gradually withdraw all greenbacks from circulation, replacing them with dollars backed in specie (i.e., gold or silver). With the [[Coinage Act of 1873|elimination of the silver dollar in 1873]], this would effectively return the United States to the [[gold standard]] for the first time since before the Civil War. Randall, who had voted against the act in 1875, agreed to let the House vote on its repeal, which narrowly passed.{{sfn|House|1934|pp=48, 125}} The Senate, still controlled by Republicans, declined to act on the bill.{{sfn|House|1934|p=125}} The attempt at repeal did not end the controversy over silver. Democratic Representative [[Richard P. Bland]] of Missouri proposed a bill that would require the United States to buy as much silver as miners could sell the government and strike it into coins, a system that would increase the money supply and aid debtors.{{sfn|Hoogenboom|1995|p=356}} In short, silver miners would sell the government metal worth fifty to seventy cents, and receive back a silver dollar. Randall allowed the bill to come to the floor for an up-or-down vote during a special session in November 1877: the result was its passage by a vote of 163 to 34 (with 94 members absent).{{efn|The absent members were mostly Eastern members, involved in elections in their homes states.{{sfn|House|1934|pp=125–126}}}}{{sfn|House|1934|pp=125–126}} The pro-silver idea cut across party lines, and [[William B. Allison]], a Republican from Iowa led the effort in the Senate.{{sfn|Hoogenboom|1995|p=356}} Allison offered an amendment in the Senate requiring the purchase of two to four million dollars per month of silver, but not allowing private deposit of silver at the mints.{{sfn|Hoogenboom|1995|pp=358–359}} Thus, the [[seignorage]], or difference between the face value of the coin and the worth of the metal contained within it accrued to the government's credit, not private citizens.{{sfn|Hoogenboom|1995|pp=358–359}} President Hayes vetoed the bill, but Congress overrode the veto, and the [[Bland–Allison Act]] became law.{{sfn|Hoogenboom|1995|pp=358–359}} ===Potter committee=== As the 1880 presidential elections approached, many Democrats remained convinced Tilden had been robbed of the presidency in 1876.{{sfn|House|1934|p=127}} In the House, Tilden supporter [[Clarkson Nott Potter]] of New York sought an investigation into the 1876 election in Florida and Louisiana, hoping that evidence of Republican malfeasance would harm that party's candidate in 1880.{{sfn|Guenther|1983|pp=283–284}} The Democratic caucus, including Randall, unanimously endorsed the idea, and the committee convened in May 1878.{{sfn|House|1934|p=127}} Some in the caucus wished to investigate the entire election, but Randall and the more moderate members worked to limit the committee's reach to the two disputed states.{{sfn|House|1934|pp=129–130}} Randall left no doubt about his sympathies when he assigned members to the committee, stacking it with Hayes's enemies from both parties.{{sfn|Hoogenboom|1995|p=366}} The committee's investigation had the opposite of the Democrats' intended effect, uncovering telegrams from Tilden's nephew, [[William Tilden Pelton]], offering bribes to Southern Republicans in the disputed states to help Tilden claim their votes.{{sfn|Guenther|1983|pp=289–291}} The Pelton telegrams were in code, which the committee was able to decode; Republicans had also sent ciphered dispatches, but the committee was unable to decode them.{{sfn|Guenther|1983|pp=289–291}} The ensuing excitement fizzled out by June 1878 as the Congress went into recess.{{sfn|Hoogenboom|1995|p=367}} ===Reelected Speaker=== {{CSS image crop |Image = Joseph Clay Stiles Blackburn - Brady-Handy.jpg |bSize = 400 |cWidth = 220 |cHeight = 270 |oTop = 30 |oLeft = 90 |Location = left |Description = Many House Democrats preferred [[Joseph Clay Stiles Blackburn|Joseph Blackburn]] to Randall as the Democrats' choice for Speaker. |Alt = A man with a large moustache, dressed in a 19th century suit. }} As the [[46th United States Congress|46th Congress]] convened in 1879, the Democratic caucus was reduced, but they still held a plurality of seats. The new House contained 152 Democrats, 139 Republicans, and 20 independents, most of whom were affiliated with the [[Greenback Party]].{{sfn|House|1934|pp=114–115}} Many of Randall's fellow Democrats differed with him over protectionism and his lack of support for Southern railroad subsidies, and considered choosing [[Joseph Clay Stiles Blackburn]] of Kentucky as their nominee for Speaker, instead.{{sfn|House|1934|pp=114–115}} Several other Southerners' names were floated, too, as anti-Randall Democrats tried to coalesce around a single candidate; in the end, none could be found and the caucus chose Randall as their nominee with 107 votes out of 152.{{sfn|House|1934|pp=114–115}} With some Democrats not yet present, however, the Democrats began to fear that the Republicans and Greenbackers would strike a deal to combine their votes to elect [[James A. Garfield]] of Ohio as Speaker.{{sfn|House|1934|pp=114–115}} When the time for the vote came, however, Garfield refused to make any compromises with the third-party men, and Randall and the Democrats were able to organize the House once more.{{sfn|House|1934|pp=114–115}} ===Civil rights and the army=== Randall's determination to cut spending, combined with Southern Democrats' desire to reduce federal power in their home states, led the House to pass an army appropriation bill with a [[Rider (legislation)|rider]] that repealed the [[Enforcement Acts]], which had been used to suppress the [[Ku Klux Klan]].{{sfn|Hoogenboom|1995|pp=392–402}} The Enforcement Acts, passed during Reconstruction over Democratic opposition, made it a crime to prevent someone from voting because of his race. Hayes was determined to preserve the law protecting black voters, and he vetoed the appropriation.{{sfn|Hoogenboom|1995|pp=392–402}} The Democrats did not have enough votes to override the veto, but they passed a new bill with the same rider. Hayes vetoed this as well, and the process was repeated three times more.{{sfn|Hoogenboom|1995|pp=392–402}} Finally, Hayes signed an appropriation without the rider, but Congress refused to pass another bill to fund federal marshals, who were vital to the enforcement of the Enforcement Acts.{{sfn|Hoogenboom|1995|pp=392–402}} The election laws remained in effect, but the funds to enforce them were curtailed.{{sfn|Hoogenboom|1995|pp=392–402}} Randall's role in the process was limited, but the Democrats' failure to force Hayes's acquiescence weakened his appeal as a potential presidential candidate in 1880.{{sfn|House|1934|pp=131–132}} ===1880 presidential election=== As the 1880 elections approached, Randall had two goals: to increase his control of the Pennsylvania Democratic Party, and to nominate Tilden for president.{{sfn|House|1934|pp=176–177}} His efforts at the former in 1875 had been successful, but Senator William Wallace's faction was again growing powerful.{{sfn|House|1934|p=161}} If he wanted to hold the Speakership, as well as to wield influence in the next presidential canvass, Randall believed he must have a united state party behind him.{{sfn|House|1934|p=161}} To that end, Randall spent much of his time outside of Congress travelling around his home state to line up support at the state convention in 1880.{{sfn|House|1934|pp=165–174}} Some of his allies' enthusiasm backfired against him, however, after McMullen and some supporters broke up an anti-Randall meeting in Philadelphia's 5th ward with such violence that one man was left dead.{{sfn|House|1934|pp=174–175}} When the state convention gathered in April 1880, Randall was confident of victory, but soon found that the Wallace faction outnumbered his.{{sfn|House|1934|pp=182–184}} Wallace's majority scrambled the party's organization in Philadelphia and, although some Randall supporters received seats, the majority owed allegiance to the senator.{{sfn|House|1934|pp=184–185}} Despite the defeat, Randall pressed on for Tilden, both in Pennsylvania and elsewhere.{{sfn|House|1934|pp=185–187}} As rumors circulated that Tilden's health would keep him from running again, Randall remained a loyal Tilden man up to the [[1880 Democratic National Convention|national convention]] that June.{{sfn|House|1960|pp=201–203}} After the first ballot, the New York delegation released a letter from Tilden in which he withdrew from consideration.{{sfn|Clancy|1958|pp=139–140}} Randall hoped for the ex-Tilden delegates to rally to him.{{sfn|House|1960|pp=210–211}} Many did so, and Randall surged to second place on the second ballot, but the momentum had shifted to another candidate, Major General [[Winfield Scott Hancock]].{{sfn|Clancy|1958|pp=139–140}} Nearly all of the delegates shifted to Hancock, and he was nominated.{{sfn|Clancy|1958|pp=139–140}} Randall believed he had been betrayed by many he had thought would support him, but carried on regardless in support of his party's nominee.{{sfn|House|1934|p=191}} Hancock (who remained on active duty) and the Republican nominee, James A. Garfield, did not campaign directly, in keeping with the customs of that time, but campaigns were conducted by other party members, including Randall.{{sfn|Ackerman|2003|pp=164–165, 202}} Speaking in Pennsylvania and around the [[Midwestern United States|Midwest]], Randall did his best to rally the people to Hancock against Garfield, but without success.{{sfn|House|1934|pp=192–193}} Garfield was elected with 214 electoral votes—including those of Pennsylvania.{{sfn|Ackerman|2003|p=221}} Worse still for Randall, Garfield's victory had swept the Republicans back into a majority in the House, meaning Randall's time as Speaker was at an end.{{sfn|Ackerman|2003|p=221}} ==Later House service== [[File:John Griffin Carlisle, Brady-Handy photo portrait, ca1870-1880.jpg|thumb|[[John G. Carlisle]] bested Randall for Speaker in 1883.]] ===Tariffs=== When Randall returned to Washington in 1881 to begin his term in the [[47th United States Congress|47th Congress]], the legislature was controlled by Republicans.{{efn|The Senate contained 37 Democrats, 37 Republicans, and two independents, one of whom caucused with each major party. Vice President [[Chester A. Arthur]] held the tie-breaking vote.{{sfn|Ackerman|2003|p=221}}}}{{sfn|Ackerman|2003|p=221}} After [[Assassination of James A. Garfield|Garfield's assassination]] later that year, Vice President [[Chester A. Arthur]] assumed the presidency. Arthur, like most Republicans, favored high tariffs, but he sought to simplify the tariff structure and to reduce excise taxes.{{sfn|Reeves|1975|pp=330–333}} Randall, who had returned to his seat on the Appropriations Committee, favored the president's plan, and was among the few Democrats in the House to support the it.{{sfn|House|1934|p=227}} The bill that emerged from the [[United States House Committee on Ways and Means|Ways and Means Committee]], dominated by protectionists, provided for only a 10 percent reduction.{{sfn|Reeves|1975|pp=330–333}} After conference with the Senate, the resulting bill had an even smaller effect, reducing tariffs by an average of 1.47 percent.{{sfn|Reeves|1975|pp=334–335}} It passed both houses narrowly on March 3, 1883, the last full day of the 47th Congress; Arthur signed [[Tariff of 1883|the measure]] into law.{{sfn|Reeves|1975|pp=334–335}} Toward the end, Randall took less part in the debate, feeling the tension between his supporters in the House, who wanted more reductions, and his constituents at home, who wanted less.{{sfn|House|1934|p=232}} The Democrats recaptured the House after the [[United States House of Representatives elections, 1882|1882 elections]], but the incoming majority in the [[48th United States Congress|48th Congress]] was divided on tariffs, with Randall's protectionist faction in the minority.{{sfn|House|1934|p=235}} The new Democratic caucus was more Southern and Western than in previous Congresses, and contained many new members who were unfamiliar with Randall.{{sfn|House|1934|p=235}} This led many to propose selecting a Speaker more in line with their own views, rather than returning Randall to the office.{{sfn|House|1934|p=236}} Randall's attempt to canvass the incoming representatives was further hampered by an attack of the [[gout]].{{sfn|House|1934|p=236}} In the end, [[John G. Carlisle]] of Kentucky, an advocate of tariff reform, bested Randall in a poll of the Democratic caucus by a vote of 104 to 53.{{sfn|House|1934|p=236}} Carlisle selected [[William Ralls Morrison]], another tariff reformer, to lead the Ways and Means committee, but allowed Randall to take charge of Appropriations.{{sfn|House|1934|pp=237–238}} Morrison's committee produced a bill proposing tariff reductions of 20%; Randall opposed the idea from the start, as did the Republicans.{{sfn|House|1934|pp=237–238}} Another bout of illness kept Randall away from Congress at a crucial time in April 1884, and the tariff bill passed a procedural hurdle by just two votes.{{sfn|House|1934|pp=239–240}} Two days later, Randall's Appropriations committee reported several funding bills with his support.{{sfn|House|1934|pp=239–240}} Many Democrats who had voted for Morrison's tariff were thereby reminded that Randall had the power to defeat spending that was important to them; when the final vote came, enough switched sides to join with Republicans in defeating the reform 156 to 151.{{sfn|House|1934|pp=240–241}} ===Presidential election of 1884=== As in 1880, the contest for the Democratic nomination for president in 1884 began under the shadow of Tilden.{{sfn|Welch|1988|pp=28–29}} Declining health forced Tilden's withdrawal by June 1884, and Randall felt free to pursue his own chance at the presidency.{{sfn|House|1934|p=242}} He gathered some of the Pennsylvania delegates to his cause, but by the time the convention assembled in July, most of the former Tilden adherents had gathered around New York governor [[Grover Cleveland]].{{sfn|Welch|1988|pp=28–29}} Early in the convention, Randall met with [[Daniel Manning]], Cleveland's campaign manager, and soon thereafter Randall's delegates were instructed to cast their votes for Cleveland.{{sfn|House|1934|p=244}} As his biographer, House, wrote, the "actual bargain struck between Randall and Manning is not known, but ... events would seem to show that Randall was promised control of federal [[Spoils system|patronage]] in Pennsylvania."{{sfn|House|1934|p=244}}{{sfn|Welch|1988|p=31}} Cleveland's campaign made extensive use of Randall, as he made speeches for Cleveland in New England, Pennsylvania, Ohio, Virginia, New York, and Connecticut, mainly in places where potential voters needed to be reassured that the Democrats did not want to lower the tariff so much that they would lose their jobs.{{sfn|House|1934|p=245}} In a close election, Cleveland was elected over his Republican opponent, James G. Blaine.{{sfn|Welch|1988|pp=40–41}} Randall also took two tours of the South in 1884 after the election.{{sfn|House|1934|p=245}} Although, he claimed the trips to be of a personal nature, they generated speculation that Randall was gathering support for another run at the Speakership in 1885.{{sfn|House|1934|p=245}} ===Resisting tariff reform=== As the [[49th United States Congress|49th Congress]] gathered in 1885, Cleveland's position on the tariff was still largely unknown. Randall declined to challenge Carlisle for Speaker, busying himself instead with the federal patronage in Pennsylvania and continued leadership of the Appropriations committee.{{sfn|House|1934|p=249}} In February 1886, Morrison, still the chairman of Ways and Means, proposed a bill to decrease the surplus by buying and cancelling $10 million worth of federal bonds each month.{{sfn|House|1934|p=249}} Cleveland opposed the plan, and Randall joined 13 Democrats and most Republicans in defeating it.{{sfn|House|1934|p=250}} Later that year, however, Cleveland supported Morrison's attempt to reduce the tariff.{{sfn|House|1934|p=250}} Again, Republicans and Randall's protectionist bloc combined to sink the measure.{{sfn|House|1934|p=250}} In the lame-duck session of 1887, Randall attempted a compromise tariff that would eliminate [[Duty (economics)|duties]] on some raw materials while also dispensing with excises on tobacco and some liquors.{{sfn|House|1934|p=252}} The bill attracted some support from Southern Democrats and Randall's protectionists, but Republicans and the rest of the Democratic caucus rejected it.{{sfn|House|1934|p=252}} ===Declining influence=== [[Image:SamuelJacksonRandall.jpg|thumb|left|Posthumous portrait of Randall by William A. Greaves, 1891]] The tariff fight continued into the [[50th United States Congress|50th Congress]], which opened in 1887, in which Democrats retained control of the House, with a reduced majority.{{sfn|House|1934|p=253}} By that time, Cleveland had openly sided with the tariff reformers and backed the proposals introduced in 1888 by Representative [[Roger Q. Mills]] of Texas.{{sfn|Welch|1988|pp=87–89}} Mills had replaced Morrison at Ways and Means after the latter's defeat for reelection, and was as much in favor of tariff reform as the Illinoisan had been.{{sfn|Welch|1988|pp=87–89}} Mills's bill would make small cuts to tariffs on raw materials, but relatively deeper cuts to those on manufactured goods; Randall, representing a manufacturing district, opposed it immediately.{{sfn|House|1934|p=253}} Randall was again ill and absent from the House when the Mills tariff passed by a 162 to 149 vote.{{sfn|House|1934|p=253}} The Senate, now Republican-controlled, refused to consider the bill, and it died with the 50th Congress in 1889.{{sfn|Welch|1988|pp=87–89}} Mills's and Cleveland's defeat on the tariff bill could be considered a victory for Randall, but the vote showed how isolated the former Speaker's protectionist ideas now made him in his party: only four Democrats voted against the tariff reductions.{{sfn|House|1934|p=254}} The state party likewise turned against Randall and toward [[free trade]], adopting a pro-tariff revision platform at the 1888 state Democratic convention.{{sfn|House|1934|p=281}} At the same time, Randall seemingly reversed his long-standing commitment to fiscal economy by voting with the Republicans to override Cleveland's veto of the [[Dependent and Disability Pension Act]].{{sfn|House|1934|p=219}} The Act would have given a pension to every Union veteran (or their widows) who claimed he could no longer perform physical labor, regardless of whether his disability was war-related.{{sfn|Welch|1988|pp=63–64}} Cleveland's veto was in line with his record of small-government cost-cutting, with which Randall would normally have sympathized. Randall, perhaps in an effort to gain favor with veterans in his district, joined the Republicans in an unsuccessful attempt to override Cleveland's veto.{{efn|The bill passed in the next Congress and was signed into law by the Republican president [[Benjamin Harrison]].{{sfn|Welch|1988|p=101}}}}{{sfn|House|1934|p=220}} Another possibility proposed by biographer House is that Randall saw the federal budget surplus as reason to cut tariffs; by increasing federal spending, he hoped to decrease the surplus and maintain the need for high tariffs.{{sfn|House|1934|p=220}} Whatever the reason, the attempt failed and left Randall further alienated from his fellow Democrats.{{sfn|House|1934|p=220}} ===Death=== Randall's positions on tariffs and pensions had made him, according to ''[[The New York Times]]'', "a practical Republican" by 1888.{{sfn|New York Times 1890}} Voting with the opposing party so frequently was an effective tactic, as he faced only token Republican opposition for reelection that year.{{sfn|House|1934|p=282}} Randall's health continued to decline. When [[51st United States Congress|the new congress]] began in 1889, he received special permission to be sworn into office from his bed, where he was confined.{{sfn|House|1934|p=282}} The new Speaker, Republican [[Thomas Brackett Reed]] of Maine, appointed Randall to the Rules and Appropriations committees, but he had no impact during that term.{{sfn|House|1934|p=282}} On April 12, 1890, Randall died of [[colon cancer]] in his Washington home.{{sfn|New York Times 1890}} He had recently joined the [[National Presbyterian Church#First Presbyterian Church|First Presbyterian Church]] in the capital, and his funeral was held there.{{sfn|House|1934|p=283}} He was buried in [[Laurel Hill Cemetery]] in Philadelphia.{{sfn|House|1934|p=283}} Elected every two years from 1862 to 1888, Randall was the only prominent Democrat continuously on the national scene between those years.{{sfn|Adams|1954|pp=48–49}} In an obituary, the Bulletin of the American Iron and Steel Association described the congressman who had consistently protected their industry: "Not a great scholar, nor a great orator, nor a great writer, Samuel J. Randall was nevertheless a man of sterling common sense, quick perceptions, great courage, broad views and extraordinary capacity for work."{{sfn|Bulletin 1890|p=108}} The only scholarly works on his life are a master's thesis by Sidney I. Pomerantz, written in 1932, and a doctoral dissertation by Albert V. House, from 1934; both are unpublished.{{sfn|Foley|2013|pp=481–482}} His papers were collected by the University of Pennsylvania library in the 1950s and he has been the subject of several journal articles (many by House), but, as of 2015, awaits a full scholarly biography.{{sfn|Foley|2013|pp=481–482}}{{sfn|Adams|1954|p=45}} ==Notes== {{notes}} ==References== {{reflist | colwidth = 26em | refs = }} ==Sources== ===Books=== {{refbegin}} * {{cite book | year = 1891 | title = Memorial Addresses on the Life and Character of Samuel J.
